question.title: Majority Element II
question.content:
Given an integer array of size n, find all elements that appear more than ⌊ n/3 ⌋ times.

 

Example 1:

Input: nums = [3,2,3]
Output: [3]

Example 2:

Input: nums = [1]
Output: [1]

Example 3:

Input: nums = [1,2]
Output: [1,2]

 

Constraints:

  • 1 <= nums.length <= 5 * 104
  • -109 <= nums[i] <= 109

 

Follow up: Could you solve the problem in linear time and in O(1) space?

hints:
How many majority elements could it possibly have?
Do you have a better hint? Suggest it!

rephrased.body: Given an integer array of size `n`, identify all elements that occur more frequently than `⌊n/3⌋` times.  In other words, find all elements that appear strictly more than one-third of the total number of elements in the array.

testcases.explanation: The element 3 appears twice in the array of size 3. Since 2 > floor(3/3) = 1, 3 is included in the output.
The element 1 appears once in the array of size 1. Since 1 > floor(1/3) = 0, 1 is included in the output.
The element 1 appears once and 2 appears once in an array of size 2. Since 1 > floor(2/3) = 0, both 1 and 2 are included in the output.
